image.altText: Paul Bartlett crouching down with a group of labradoodles.

props.synopsis: The RSPCA is investigating if criminal charges are possible for the former owners of Tasmania's largest puppy farm, in the wake of an ABC report that aired concerns from former workers.

title.children: RSPCA takes steps to pursue Tasmanian Labradoodles owners for new charges

image.altText: Hobart bus mall in Elizabeth Street

props.synopsis: Bus drivers at Metro Tasmania will be able to access critical incident leave, which their union says will help drivers cope with ongoing violent and antisocial behaviour.

title.children: Metro bus drivers get critical incident leave after striking

image.altText: A concept image of the proposed Hobart stadium at Macquarie Poi nt.

props.synopsis: The $240 million in Commonwealth funding for the Macquarie Point stadium and precinct will now be exempt from Tasmania's GST calculations, leaving more money for the state and ending a months-long war of words.

title.children: Parties line up to claim credit over federal Hobart stadium funding GST backflip

props.synopsis: Thousands of buoys used for science end up as marine waste â€” one Tasmanian group is helping to change this. They've created a wooden prototype that can survive the ocean's harshest conditions.

title.children: Wooden buoys developed to aid research while reducing marine waste

image.altText: Gregory Geason wearing a blue suit with bus in background

props.synopsis: Former Tasmanian Supreme Court judge Gregory Geason pleaded guilty in a NSW court to one count of contravening a restriction specified in an AVO.

title.children: Former Supreme Court judge sentenced after breaching domestic violence order

image.altText: Spirit of Tasmania new ferry funnel lifted by cranes into place.

props.synopsis: The fit-outs for the new Spirit ferries were initially pledged to include up to $100 million in "Tasmanian local content", but the state government says that now includes Australia-wide businesses and big multinationals.

title.children: Apple and other multinationals counted as 'local content' for new Spirit ferries fit-out

image.altText: A helicopter view of Robert Greig's ute on fire in the middle of a forest.

props.synopsis: A Tasmanian father says he now accepts police played no role in the death of his fugitive son in 2022 â€” with an inquest hearing the theory originated with the operator of a Facebook news page.

title.children: Grieving father now accepts cops didn't kill fugitive son

image.altText: A man with a cropped beard and glasses stands outside a school building.

props.synopsis: A former principal in Tasmania is sentenced to a home detention order over the persistent sexual abuse of a student in the 1980s.

title.children: Former Tasmanian principal sentenced to home detention for sexual abuse of student

image.altText: Japanese macaques in an enclosure.

props.synopsis: Launceston City Council has voted to sterilise the popular troop of macaque monkeys living in City Park as they are becoming inbred.

title.children: Did you miss? ðŸ“£ Tasmanian council decides to let beloved City Park monkeys die out

image.altText: A groundskeeper sits in a buggy during in the rain on day one of the third Test between Australia and India.

props.synopsis: Play on the first day of the third Test between Australia and India in Brisbane is washed out with only 13.2 overs bowled, thanks to an almighty downpour at the Gabba.

title.children: Australia and India frustrated as heavy rain washes out most of day one

image.altText: Composite image of Nathan McSweeney, Mohammed Siraj and Usman Khawaja on day one of the third Test between Australia and India.

props.synopsis: Mohammed Siraj cops boos from the fans, who get their money back as rain restricts day one to just 13 overs, but there was still time for Australia's openers to impress. Here are the quick hits from the first day at the Gabba.

title.children: Five quick hits: Fans take aim at new Indian villain and get a refund for rain-soaked day

image.altText: Men with pixilated features look at the camera, inside a factory.

props.synopsis: Migrant workers allege exploitation by Kawaguchi Manufacturing, accusing the supplier for Sony, Panasonic and Daikin of not paying wages and withholding passports.

title.children: Sony, Panasonic 'cut and run' from Malaysian supplier accused of wage theft

image.altText: A 12-year-old boy looks at an iPhone screen showing various social media apps including TikTok, Facebook and X

props.synopsis: Psychologist Jonathan Haidt is calling for parents and policymakers to roll back the "phone-based childhood", which he says is "hurting" child and adolescent mental health.

title.children: Exposing children to smartphones before 14 is 'insanity', US expert says

image.altText: A man wedged between two woman, all wearing sunglasses while smiling at the camera by the beach

props.synopsis: Kerryn Draper was among hundreds of Australians stranded in Bali after a recent volcanic eruption. She returned with a cautionary tale about the financial and mental pressure of not being able to get home.Â

title.children: How a long-awaited dream trip to Bali quickly turned sour

image.altText: A young white woman who is blind holding a large straw hat

props.synopsis: Next time you're scrolling for bargains online, consider the half a million Australians who don't find shopping on the web fun or simple, writes Nas Campanella.

title.children: 'Like you don't matter': Why Aussies like me struggle with online shopping

image.altText: Rachael Gunn says she was "blindsided" by the musical.

props.synopsis: The Olympic breaker says she had been "blindsided" by the musical and only heard about it through media reports.Â

title.children: Raygun explains decision to trademark name and shut down comedian's musical

image.altText: Rupert Murdoch looks directly at the camera with a neutral expression.

props.synopsis: Rupert Murdoch wanted to give son Lachlan future control over his empire by stripping power from his other children. But a court rejected his plan.

title.children: A court ruling has blown up Rupert Murdoch's succession plan

image.altText: A woman with curly blonde hair sitting at a microphone in front of multiple ABC NEWS logos.

props.synopsis: Last month, Housing Minister Clare O'Neil told triple j that the government wasn't trying to bring down house prices. The interview found a new life online this week, so we asked the experts what they think.Â

title.children: Economists respond to minister insisting house prices shouldn't fall

image.altText: alleged false cancer victim

props.synopsis: An Adelaide couple remain in custody over allegations they falsely claimed their six-year-old son was undergoing cancer treatment and received $60,000 in donations. Here's what we know.

title.children: Police allege a couple faked son's cancer to claim donations. Here's what we know

image.altText: A man wearing a cap, silver aviator sunglasses and a tan-coloured hat smiles in a selfie, with white and tan roofs behind him

props.synopsis: A UK coroner has ruled that Daniel Burke died after being shot multiple times while unarmed in Ukraine, with the inquest told an Australian-Algerian dual national had confessed to his death.

title.children: Australian a suspect in 'unlawful killing' of ex-UK soldier in Ukraine

image.altText: Prince Andrew stands outside Westminster Abbey at the thanksgiving service for Prince Philip.

props.synopsis: A statement from Andrew's office said that the Duke of York had "followed advice" from the government and "ceased all contact with the individual after concerns were raised".

title.children: Prince Andrew says he 'ceased all contact' with suspected Chinese spy

image.altText: Two sitting figures are seen in silhouette against the ocean and last light of the setting sun.

props.synopsis: Australians on the front line of climate change are fighting to save their vanishing ancestral home. Can a landmark lawsuit against the federal government save their way of life?

title.children: Islanders fight to keep hope and culture alive as Torres Strait rises

image.altText: A man and a woman in formal wear walk through soldiers in gold hats featuring plumes

props.synopsis: The Syrian regime was also one of the world's biggest drug syndicates. What happens to the multi-billion-dollar drug trade now that the "narco-state" has fallen?

title.children: Uncertainty swirls around tiny pill that reanimated Syria's zombie economy

image.altText: An artisan makes traditional West Javanese puppets called wayang

props.synopsis: An elite school will soon ditch a long-running language program, in a move experts say could be "ideological" and will leave Australia ill-equipped to engage with our closest Asian neighbour.

title.children: Elite school drops key Asian language in 'huge backwards step'

image.altText: Teenager with racing car.

props.synopsis: At least 600 kilometres from his nearest racing track, country teen Jett Zerk will train each day on his Xbox in his bedroom before heading to Bathurst.

title.children: Teen set to be one of the youngest drivers ever to hit Bathurst track

image.altText: A smiling mum and dad holding their small baby.

props.synopsis: Ocie Ni Dheasmhunaigh has a form of dwarfism so extremely rare, she's one of only three known cases in Australia. The "happy little girl" recently underwent surgery to avoid pain later in life.

title.children: Ocie's rare form of dwarfism was diagnosed soon after her first birthday

image.altText: A close-up film still of Tommy Dewey, made up like a monster, smiling, his fists resting under his chin.

props.synopsis: After Laura's boyfriend dumps her while she's in hospital recovering from cancer surgery, she finds herself falling for the creature who terrorised her as a child in this bizarre future cult classic.

title.children: Would you date a man or a monster? The lead in this film picks the latter

image.altText: An illustration of a glowing yellow sun and people floating among stacks of books

props.synopsis: Here's our wrap of the best books of 2024. Novels by Sally Rooney, Tim Winton and Booker Prize winner Samantha Harvey top our critics' favourite reads of the year.

title.children: Sex, chess and time travel: Welcome to the best books of 2024

image.altText: Two glass jars filled with Eton mess ready for serving for Christmas dessert, with passionfruit curd, strawberries and mint.

props.synopsis: Pavlova is considered a classic dessert for summer celebrations, but Eton mess is a cooler, less fussy option.Â

title.children: Intimidated by pavlova? Make Eton mess instead

image.altText: Hornsy plan graphic with Parramatta Westfield tower plan and Westfield logo under microscope together in graphic

props.synopsis: One of Australia's largest shopping centre operators is exploring whether it can build apartments on 42 of its shopping centres. But while some claim this could help the affordable housing crisis, others have reservations.

title.children: Would you live in an apartment on top of a Westfield shopping centre?

image.altText: Split cherries amongst leaves.

props.synopsis: The country's two largest cherry producing states lose a third of their fruit due to heavy rain, which could see prices rise.

title.children: Rain-hit cherries 'explode' in several states, slashing Christmas supply

props.synopsis: Middle East correspondent Eric Tlozek travels to the Syrian capital to get a first look inside the country since the fall of the Assad dictatorship.

title.children: The ABC takes its first look inside Damascus after the fall of the Assad regime

image.altText: man looking out to a dam

props.synopsis: The Fosterville Gold Mine wants to expand its operations for another decade but the impact on its neighbours already is taking a toll, a government inquiry has been told.Â

title.children: Gold mine admits 100 more homes in the 'impact zone' if it expands

image.altText: crisafulli speaking during question time

props.synopsis: No issue proved more of a headache for David Crisafulli on the election campaign trail than abortion, writes Jack McKay.Â

title.children: Queensland premier reveals unorthodox solution to his abortion issue

image.altText: Boxer Justis Huni is seen posing for a photograph, with a clinched fist outstretched towards the camera

props.synopsis: Australian heavyweight Justis Huni is aiming to climb further up the world boxing rankings when he defends his WBO Global heavyweight title against South Africa's Shaun Potgieter.

title.children: Huni to defend boxing title against 'God's Warrior'
